text: Hello, my name is Brivael Le Pogam.
I am Co-Founder of a company called Argil.ai.

At Argil, we are developing video avatar technology that
allows any content creator to create their own asset,

their own digital clone, so that they can create content
on the fly using generative AI.

The application is quite simple, with a two-minute
video of yourself, you can create your own digital clone.

And with this digital clone, you can recreate content on
the fly, without having to go through the video process.

So, we use different technologies,
in particular speech-to-text, text-to-speech,
to generate the audio for a video.

And we've developed an AI avatar model that can recreate
a photo-realistic video of yourself using a two-minute dataset.

The challenges we've faced in developing and working in AI are
often scalability, particularly when we're doing fine-tuning
on models.

It's figuring out how to keep
this ability to fine-tune models and scale them.
So, it's often linked to architecture and infrastructure.

AWS stack will enable us to make much
faster progress with this.

But generally speaking, the challenges
are often linked to having a stable model.

For our avatar video in particular,
it was easy to get the zero to 95%.
What's always hard is getting 5% of the edge case.

And that's a long-term effort, because it means doing
a huge amount of data sets to try and find out where it works
and where it doesn't work.
We've migrated all the machine learning to AWS,

in particular with AWS Batch, which gives us a fairly
robust and scalable infrastructure from scratch.

The advantages of AWS were the simplicity of migration, 
the ability to scale day one on our infrastructure because

that's important, and the interconnection between
the different services, particularly the logging systems.

that's important, and the interconnection between
the different services, particularly the logging systems.

is always very responsive.
For example, we needed to increase quotas quite quickly.

I always get a response within the hour and the solution
is always there.
It's always quite fluid.

The migration was also fairly, fairly quick because we don't
have a huge stack.
And what's cool is that in a fortnight

we were able to migrate our ML stack quite
quickly, so it's quite, I'd say, simple, efficient and fluid.

I think the credit system is quite
beneficial for

early-stage AI startups because
there's a lot of room for R&D and exploration.
So obviously, when you have a credit system, you can test

things that you might not be able to do if you had,
if you paid directly.
It's an ecosystem that's still very new, very early.

So having this safety net of cloud
credits, let's face it, is pretty, pretty cool.

We have AI models that we use outsource,
particularly for text-to-speech.
We didn't develop this technology in-house.

For the model part, our video avatar model, we've read
all the research papers

on the subject, we've tested
all the open-source technologies, so we
own that part in-house.

So, we've developed, it's been, it's been about seven months
since we started, so we've been inspired by the best research
papers on the subject, and

we're using technologies,
but at a much lower level than turnkey models.

And we own the whole stack of the training, pre-training
and inference part which allows us to be fairly cost-effective

and in particular to deploy this on AWS and have a cost that
is affordable enough to be able to market directly afterward.

So, it's quite cross-disciplinary, but it's often
a mixture of pure machine learning, so math, the infrastructure

and the ability to find a way of creating
a kind of feedback loop to move forward properly.
We're extremely concerned about ethical issues because

we create deepfakes, so it's a matter that's bound
to be regulated in the next few years.
There are still major legal loopholes, but in any case,

on our side, for example, we don't allow just anyone
to do anything, to play around with just any image.

So, there has to be a consent video when someone wants to make
deepfakes.
We also take the same approach to content.
We always check content that has

been generated on the platform, in particular
all the political subjects and so on,
were pretty careful about that.
Partly because we're in the process

of creating a marketplace of actors
that will allow people to use other people's images.

So, we take this subject very
seriously, especially as these use cases

have the potential to be the most
dangerous if they are done in the wrong way.

In terms of AWS building blocks
we use from an AI point of view, we're currently focusing more
on the low-level layers, so
mainly EC2 with attached GPUs, with AWS Batch for scalability.

We're also exploring AWS Bedrock for
the text generation part, in particular with Cloud

Anthropic because we can face challenges with pre-production,
particularly when generating content for our users.

So, we're still in the exploration phase, but we haven't
yet implemented anything in these areas.
Our marketing strategy is super fun.
In particular, we started two months ago with videos.

I could mention a video of Mark Anderson that we made that was
quite, quite playful.
We always make it very clear that it's a deepfake.
We're always quite considerate, but we have

quite a viral marketing strategy, and it's working
quite well.

From our videos
on Twitter, we gained 10,000 visitors on our waiting list.

I think it's always hard to look five, or ten years into the
future because I think we're basically on an exponential path.
I think that video production costs will plummet.

That doesn't necessarily
mean that the video production business will disappear.

But I do think that the video
production market is going to change radically.

In my view, the availability of genAI
tools means that the technical side of things will be reduced

to a minimum, and content creators will be able to focus
on creation rather than on the technical side.

So that's rather positive. Today, we've created
a technology that allows us to recreate the entire face.
Obviously, the next step would be to recreate the whole body.

So, I think that, basically, creating a masterclass
so that someone who has expertise in whatever subject will
soon be able to create a full digital clone.

So, with all that that implies in terms of control over
body language, given that we focus

on content creators, we're quite committed to the idea of
giving a huge amount of control, particularly over

the ability to control body language and when you're
targeting social networks, it's quite important to be engaging.

The vision, I think that things that are not yet possible
today in terms of video generation will be possible

in the future, because the costs of GPEs are on an inverted
exponential scale, and I think that

we're going to see a tenfold
or even a hundredfold increase in the years to come.

And generally speaking,
these tools are going to be increasingly

controllable, cost-effective and permissive
for creating content.

The main use cases we have involve creating educational

We don't target companies
